Method Detail

test_2_1_10_1_PROMPT

public void test_2_1_10_1_PROMPT()
                          throws java.lang.Exception
Test SignalDetector.PROMPT.

A LoopbackMediaGroup provides a Recorder and a SignalDetector that face each other.
The prompt file (argument of PROMPT) contains a modulated DTMF.
When the "player" Signal Detection operation starts, the prompt is played, and the DTMF triggers the SignalDetector as "detector". 

     SignalDetector     <----->   SignalDetector
  mySigDetWithPrompt              mySigDet
 
               prompt   ------>
                                                detected

Throws:
java.lang.Exception

test_2_1_10_2_Prompt_BargeIn

public void test_2_1_10_2_Prompt_BargeIn()
                                  throws java.lang.Exception
Test the barge-in feature of the Signal detector.

This test case is based on PromptAndRecordTest.test_2_1_9_2_Prompt_BargeIn() - a similar functional test for recorder. "barge-in" means that the caller interrupts the prompt with a DTMF key, indicating that he/she wishes to prematurely end the prompt phase, and start the DTMF collection phase right away.
This method has two steps: first, test with barge-in disabled, and then, test with barge-in enabled.

A LoopbackMediaGroup provides a SignalDetector facing a Player and a SignalDetector: 

           Player (myPlayer)            <------------>           SignalDetector     
   SignalDetector (myPromptDetector)                           (mySigDetWithPrompt)
The detection is started with a prompt (using SignalDetector.PROMPT).
The prompt file contains:
"cago-cago-cago-cago-cago-cago-cago-cago-DTMF2"
If barge-in is not enabled, the prompt file will always be played to the end, and the DMTF2 can be caught by a SignalDetector that listens on the other end.
If barge-in is enabled, the prompt is stopped by a DTMF1 sent by the Player, and the SignalDetector remains idle. 
 1) barge-in disabled:
 time
                                                           receiveSignals() with "prompt"
  0.0s                                          <-- cago ---   <-- prompt
  0.5s                                          <-- cago ---
  1.0s   play("dtmf1")  --->     -- DTMF1 -->   <-- cago ---
  1.5s                                                                                    <-- cago ---
  2.0s                                                            <-- cago ---
  2.5s                                                                <-- cago ---
  3.0s                                          <-- cago ---
  3.5s                                          <-- cago ---
  4.0s receiveSignals                                             <-- DTMF2---
  SignalDetectorEvent for DTMF 2<--        
           |                                                   --> SignalDetectorEvent for DTMF 1
           V
     [[ end of test ]]

 2) barge-in enabled:
 time
                                                             receiveSignals() with "prompt"
  0.0s                                          <-- cago ---   <-- prompt
  0.5s                                          <-- cago ---
  1.0s   play("dtmf1")  --->     -- DTMF1 -->   <-- cago --- [[ prompt stopped ]]                                         
  1.5s                                                                                          --> SignalDetectorEvent for DTMF 1
  2.0s                           
  2.5s   receiveSignals <--
  3.0s
  3.5s                                       (silence)  -->
  4.0s receiveSignals 
  ...   wait for 10 seconds, no event                           
             |
             V
       [[ end of test ]]
Test assumptions:
With barge-in disabled, the test must end by a SignalDetectorEvent with DTMF2.
With barge-in enabled, the test must end by a time out on receiving Signals.

Throws:
java.lang.Exception

test_2_1_10_3_Cancel

public void test_2_1_10_3_Cancel()
                          throws java.lang.Exception
Test that SignalDetector.CANCEL is efficient.

A LoopbackMediaGroup provides a Player and a SignalDetector that face each other.
The SignalDetector is started with the RTC:
(SignalDetector.PATTERN_MATCH[2], SignalDetector.CANCEL)
and SignalDetector.PATTERN[2] is defined by "3".

The Player plays the DTMFs "1", "2", "3", "4", etc.
The SignalDetector must stop with qualifier ResourceEvent.RTC_TRIGGERED, and RTCTrigger SignalDetector.PATTERN_MATCH[2].

Throws:
java.lang.Exception

test_2_1_10_4_CancelWithPrompt

public void test_2_1_10_4_CancelWithPrompt()
                                    throws java.lang.Exception
Test that SignalDetector.CANCEL is efficient also during the prompt phase.

Same test as test_2_1_10_3_Cancel(), with an additional SignalDetector.PROMPT argument, and barge-in enabled by MediaGroup.SIGDET_STOPPLAY.

Throws:
java.lang.Exception

test_2_1_10_5_Cleardigits

public void test_2_1_10_5_Cleardigits()
                               throws java.lang.Exception
Test the "cleardigits" feature.

Cleardigits is set with RTC(Player.PLAY_START, SignalDetector.FLUSH_BUFFER).

The setup is composed of a SignalDetector named "mySigDetWithPrompt" facing a Player named "myPlayer", in a LoopbackMediaGroup.
Operations: 

   mySigDetWithPrompt    <----->   myPlayer
   
                         <------   play DTMF 1              
 
 receiveSignals(prompt)   ------> [[ digits are cleared here if cleardigit is true ]]
 
          [end of prompt]
               
                         <------   play DTMF 1 2 3 
     getSignalString()

When cleardigits is true, getSignalString() returns "12", otherwise it returns "11".

Throws:
java.lang.Exception
